awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides continued funding for a 3D High Definition (HD) video documentary about an international group of earth scientists engaged in an investigation of the processes responsible for central Mongolia's unusually active uplifting terrain (the Hangay Dome) and its consequences for regional climate patterns and ecosystems (EAR -1009702).  The Hangay Dome in central Mongolia provides an excellent and accessible laboratory to investigate these processes and determine the degree to which mantle upwelling, mafic underplating, lithospheric foundering or plume activity have been important agents in its uplift.

The research project as a whole will be the focus of a feature-length documentary film (Mongolia 3D) aimed at Earth-science education and public outreach, and primary and interpreted project data will be available on the web for use in classrooms at various levels. The 3D video format is a new immersive television medium that has emerged from the highly successful 3D feature film format, and Mongolia 3D will be among the pioneering documentary productions fully produced, from inception to delivery, in 3D.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This award continued the production of a 3D and 2D documentary about international collaborations of earth scientists engaged in cutting-edge research in Asia. Activities under this project involved pre-production planning and research, filming researchers doing fieldwork and lab analyses, and continuing to develop potential avenues of 3D- and 2D-content distribution. The researchers were filmed working in the countries of Mongolia, Nepal, and the U.S. In Mongolia researchers were probing the reasons behind central Mongolia’s unusually active, rising terrain and its consequences for regional climate patterns and ecosystems; in Nepal they were pinpointing seismic hazards and learning more of the uplift of the Himalayas; in the U.S. they were analzing rock samples in state-of-the-art laboratories. The planned documentary--to be crafted for public audiences under a future project--is intended for a primary audience of television viewers watching PBS and international stations and a 3D-television channel; the film’s secondary audience will be visitors to a 3D exhibit or screenings in science museums and other public venues. The documentary will also include footage from a separate project filmed in Bangladesh, where researchers were studying dangerous seismic hazards as well the effects of climate change on millions of people in this vulnerable, low-lying country. The filmmakers, Doug Prose and Diane LaMacchia of Earth Images Foundation, are award-winning producers of earth science television documentaries and early adopters of 3D-media production.

 

Broader Impacts. The earth science field research captured on 3D video during this project is cutting edge, multidisciplinary, international, and aimed at exploring earth science topics that are relevant to the safety and quality of life for millions of people. The nature of the scientific activities filmed, set in visually dramatic locations, will readily translate into a compelling documentary story for a broad public audience. The envisioned final products, in both 3D and 2D formats, will be timely, in that public attention and concern over geologic hazards and climate change is high. The immersive 3D format has high potential to attract traditionally hard-to-reach youth and adult viewers and to more compellingly depict an international group of scientists doing field work in interesting geological and cultural settings, thus providing an improved way to communicate complex science to a wider audience and to inspire young people to consider the earth sciences as a career option, potentially contributing to increased enrollments and diversity in undergraduate Earth science programs. The 2D documentary will reach millions of people on educational television stations worldwide. Depicting the vital role that earth science research plays in improving public safety in geologically- -and climatically--active regions should have the impact of enhancing public support for earth science research.
